nodes.text: Absolute income mobility in the United States has declined since 1940 and this decline is primarily driven by a more unequal distribution of economic growth rather than lower GDP growth alone

We developed a method to estimate cohort absolute mobility by combining three components: marginal income distributions for parents and children and the copula (joint distribution of parent and child income ranks)

Data sources: children marginal distributions from CPS (March supplements), parents marginal distributions from pooled decennial Census IPUMS samples, and copula for 1980s cohorts from de-identified tax records covering >10 million parent-child pairs

Where historical panel copula is unavailable (pre-1980), we assume copula stability as a benchmark and compute tight nonparametric upper and lower bounds over all plausible copulas using linear programming with first-order stochastic dominance (FOSD) constraints

Baseline measurement choices: pretax family income at age 30 in 2014 dollars using CPI-U-RS; parents and children measured within symmetric age windows around 30; immigrants excluded for sample consistency
Assumption and constraint on plausible copulas: child income distributions weakly increase with parent income (FOSD), which excludes perverse negative-persistence copulas
We conduct sensitivity analyses (alternative deflators, taxes and transfers, income at age 40, family-size adjustments, individual vs family income) and heterogeneity analyses by state and gender
Main empirical result: under the benchmark copula stability, fraction of children earning more than their parents fell from about 92% for the 1940 birth cohort to 50% for the 1984 birth cohort

Bounds result: when searching over all plausible copulas subject to FOSD, absolute mobility for the 1940 cohort is tightly bounded between 84% and 98%, implying robust decline despite missing historical panel data

Mechanism for bounds width: early cohorts show large upward shifts in child vs parent marginal distributions (little overlap) so copula matters little; recent cohorts show substantial overlap so copula uncertainty yields wide bounds

Sensitivity finding: the decline in absolute mobility is robust to alternative inflation measures, accounting for taxes and transfers, measuring income at older ages, adjusting for family size, and reasonable upward adjustments to reported child incomes

Heterogeneity: absolute mobility declined in all 50 states from 1940 to 1980 with especially large declines in industrial Midwest states; sons experienced a much larger decline in individual earnings relative to fathers than daughters

Counterfactual simulations: reallocating observed 2010 GDP by 1940 income shares (more broadly shared growth) would raise absolute mobility for 1980 cohort to ~80%, whereas raising GDP growth to mid-century rates but keeping 2010 distribution yields ~62%
Synthesis claim: most of the decline in absolute mobility is attributable to a more unequal distribution of economic growth (distributional changes), not primarily to aggregate growth slowdown

Conclusion: reviving high historical rates of absolute mobility would require economic growth that is shared more broadly across the income distribution; higher GDP growth alone, under current distribution, is insufficient
